title: Question 69

children: A 55-year-old man is evaluated for fever, night sweats, cough with sputum production, and a 6.8-kg (15 lb) weight loss over the past 2 months. He was diagnosed with HIV infection 3 months ago but has not started antiretroviral therapy. He has a history of alcohol use disorder and was incarcerated 5 years ago.
On physical examination, temperature is 38.4 °C (101.1 °F); other vital signs are normal. Crackles are heard bilaterally in the lung bases.
Chest radiograph shows paratracheal lymphadenopathy and bilateral interstitial infiltrates.
Sputum Gram stain and cultures are negative. Acid-fast bacilli stain is positive; yeasts are not identified.
Which of the following is the most likely cause of his infection?

). He has several risk factors for active pulmonary tuberculosis, including HIV infection, alcohol use disorder, and history of incarceration. His complex of symptoms, including ongoing fever, night sweats, weight loss, and productive cough, also indicate likely tuberculosis. Although a tuberculin skin test or interferon-γ release assay would be useful and should be performed for all suspected tuberculosis infections, it may not be positive in this patient with a CD4 cell count of 200/µL.
In immunocompetent patients, symptoms of pulmonary histoplasmosis (

) are typically mild, with headache, fever, and cough, which usually resolve after a few weeks. Although data are limited, patients with HIV infection and CD4 cell counts of 200/µL or greater may present similarly to immunocompetent persons. In this patient, with a more protracted and symptomatic course, negative yeast following bronchoalveolar lavage, and positive acid-fast bacilli stain, pulmonary tuberculosis is a more likely diagnosis.

MAC is generally diagnosed by bone marrow biopsy or blood culture for mycobacterial organisms. However, MAC is rarely seen in patients with HIV with CD4 cell counts greater than 50/µL.
